===Cabinet ministers=== {{Further|List of female foreign ministers|List of female defence ministers|List of female finance ministers}} [[Alexandra Kollontai]] became the first female to hold a ministerial position, as the People's Commissar for Social Welfare in [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Soviet Russia]] in October 1917.<ref name=":6" /> [[Yevgenia Bosch]] held the position of [[Minister of Interior]] and Acting Leader of the [[People's Secretariat|People's Secretariat of Ukraine]] from December 1917 to March 1918. The [[Constance Markievicz|Countess Markievicz]] was [[Minister of Labour]] in the [[Irish Republic]] from 1919 to 1922. [[Nina Bang]], Danish Minister of Education from 1924–26, was the world's first female cabinet minister in an internationally recognized government.
While women's representation as ministers grew through the 20th century, women holding the most senior cabinet posts was relatively rare until the 21st century. In recent years, women have increasingly held the top profile portfolios for their governments in non-traditional areas for women in government, such as foreign relations, defense and national security, and finance or revenue.
=== Governors and chief ministers === {{Further|List of female constituent and dependent territory leaders}}{{See also|List of first women governors and/or chief ministers}} [[Evgenia Bosh|Yevgenia Bosch]], the [[Bolshevik]] military leader, held the People's Secretary of Internal Affairs position in the Ukraine People's Republic of the Soviets of Workers and Peasants from 1917–1918, which was responsible for executive functions of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], part of the [[Russian Soviet Republic]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guide2womenleaders.com/Premier_Ministers.htm|title=Woman Prime Ministers|website=guide2womenleaders.com|publisher=Worldwide Guide to Women in Leadership}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldstatesmen.org/Ukraine.html|title=Ukraine|website=worldstatesmen.org|publisher=World Statesmen}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=1261011&cat_id=661258|title=Yevgenia Bosch (1879–1925)|website=kmu.gov.ua|publisher=Government of Ukraine|language=uk}}</ref>
[[Nellie Tayloe Ross|Nellie Ross]] was the first [[List of female state governors in the United States|woman to be sworn in as governor]] of a [[U.S. state]] in January 1925, followed later that month by [[Miriam A. Ferguson]].
[[Louise Schroeder]] was the first female member of the [[Weimar National Assembly]]. After the division of Germany following World War II, she served as [[Governing Mayor of Berlin|governing mayor]] of [[West Berlin]] from 1948–1951.
[[Sucheta Kripalani]] was India's first woman [[Chief Minister (India)|Chief Minister]], serving as the head of the [[Uttar Pradesh]] government from 1963 to 1967.
[[Savka Dabčević-Kučar]], of the [[Socialist Republic of Croatia]] (1967–1969), was the first female premier of a non-sovereign European constituent state. She held the position of [[Prime Minister of Croatia#Prime Ministers of the Socialist Republic of Croatia within SFR Yugoslavia (1945–1990)|Chairman of the Executive Council]] (Prime Minister) of Croatia when it was a constituent republic of [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia]].
[[Imelda Marcos]] was [[Governor of Metro Manila]] in the Philippines from 1975 until 1986 when the [[People Power Revolution]] unseated the Marcoses and forced the family into exile.
[[Griselda Álvarez]] was the first female [[governor]] in [[Mexico]], serving as governor of the state of [[Colima]] from 1979 to 1985.
[[Carrie Lam]] became the first female [[Chief Executive of Hong Kong]] in 2017 and before that was [[Chief Secretary for Administration]] from 2012.
[[Claudia Sheinbaum]] is the first female mayor of [[Mexico City]]. She is the head of the most populous governmental jurisdiction administered by a woman in the [[Americas]], and third most in the world (after Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, and Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina of Bangladesh).
==Women's suffrage== {{Main|Women's suffrage movement|Suffrage|Universal suffrage}} In some languages, and occasionally in English, the right to vote is called [[active suffrage]], as distinct from [[passive suffrage]], which is the right to stand for election.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aceproject.org/main/english/lf/lfd02.htm?toc|title=Deprivation of the Right to Vote – ACE Electoral Knowledge Network|publisher=Aceproject.org|access-date=21 June 2013}}</ref> The combination of active and passive suffrage is sometimes called ''full suffrage''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.glbtq.com/social-sciences/womens_suffrage_movement.html|title=>> social sciences >> Women's Suffrage Movement|publisher=glbtq|url-status=bot: unknown|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150614133927/http://www.glbtq.com/social-sciences/womens_suffrage_movement.html|archive-date=14 June 2015|access-date=21 June 2013}}</ref>
